content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been struggling a lot lately. My wife and I are having a really tough time at home, and it feels like everything's falling apart—even my son is acting out a lot, and we don’t know how to handle it. It’s been hard to focus on work or enjoy anything, honestly. My wife pushed me to come here, but I just... I don’t know how this is supposed to help.

It sounds like things have been very difficult for you at home, and it makes sense that it’s been hard to focus or feel enjoyment with so much on your plate. It’s not easy to open up about these struggles, so I appreciate you sharing this with me. What would you say is making it especially hard for you right now?

I think the hardest part is seeing my son struggle and feeling like I can't do anything to help him. It's like no matter what my wife and I try, nothing seems to work, and on top of it all, it's causing so much tension between us. I just feel really stuck.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of worry—for your son, your relationship with your wife, and how it’s all affecting your family. It’s tough when you’re trying so hard to help, but it feels like your efforts aren’t making a difference. What has it been like for you to navigate through this feeling of being stuck?

It’s been exhausting, honestly. I feel like I’m failing as a parent and as a husband, and it’s hard to see a way out of it. I’m constantly on edge, and even when I’m not with my family, it’s all I can think about. I just don't know how to fix this.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure to hold everything together, and it's leaving you emotionally drained. It’s clear how much you care about your family and want to do what's right for them, even though things feel overwhelming right now. What do you think might help you take a step forward, just for yourself or for your family?

I honestly don’t know. I feel so stuck that it’s hard to even imagine anything helping at this point. Maybe if I could figure out how to help my son, that could be a start, but I don’t even know where to begin with that. It’s been such a mess.

It's understandable that feeling stuck makes it hard to see a way forward, especially when you just want the best for your son and your family. It sounds like helping him is really important to you and might even bring a sense of relief for everyone. Would it be helpful to explore what might be going on for him or some small steps you and your wife might take together to support him?

It's hard when you feel lost on how to help the people you love most. Starting with your son sounds like it’s really important to you, and it might also give you and your wife a shared focus to work on together. Have you been able to talk with your son or maybe understand more about why he’s been acting out?

We’ve tried talking to him, but he mostly shuts down or gets upset. It’s so frustrating because I want to connect with him and understand what’s really going on, but it feels like there’s this wall between us. I don’t want to push him too hard, but I also don’t want to just ignore the behavior either. It’s tough to know where to even start.

That does sound really hard, especially when you’re trying to reach him but feel like you’re hitting a wall. It’s clear that you care deeply and want to connect with him. How does he usually respond when you and your wife try to address his behavior or talk to him about how he’s feeling?

He either avoids the conversation completely or gets really angry. He’ll storm off to his room and slam the door. It’s a bit of a cycle at this point, where we bring something up, he reacts badly, and then we all just kind of retreat to our corners, not sure what to do next. It’s like we’re stuck in this never-ending loop.

That sounds like such a tough place to be in—it’s clear how much you want to break that cycle and reach him. It might help to take a different approach, maybe finding a way to connect with him outside of those difficult conversations first, or working with someone who specializes in kids' behavior. Have you thought about involving someone, like a counselor or therapist for him, or even a family therapist to help all of you navigate this together?

We’ve talked about it a little, but honestly, I’m not even sure if he’d be open to it. And it feels like admitting that we’ve failed as parents if we need to bring someone else in to help. I know that probably sounds stubborn, but it’s just how I feel right now.

It doesn’t sound stubborn at all—it sounds like you’re carrying so much pressure and responsibility as a parent, which makes it hard to ask for help. Wanting to figure this out on your own is completely understandable, especially when it’s your child. But the fact that you’re even here and open to talking about all of this shows that you care deeply and are willing to try for him and your family. Do you think exploring that kind of support together with your wife could take some of this burden off your shoulders?

Yeah, maybe. I guess it could help to have someone guide us since we’re kind of at a loss right now. I don’t want to feel like we’re fighting all the time anymore, and if it could help us and help my son, then maybe it’s worth considering.

It’s great that you’re open to the idea—it shows how much you’re trying to do what’s best for your family. Moving forward together with your wife and exploring support for your son could be a really good first step. You don’t have to face all of this alone. What do you think about talking to your wife about the idea of finding someone who could help you tackle this together?

I think having that conversation with her is a good idea. I know she’s feeling just as overwhelmed as I am, and maybe she’d be on board with it if we realized we both could use the help. It’s worth talking to her about.

That sounds like a really good starting point. It might even bring you both closer to be able to approach this as a team. And if you’re both feeling overwhelmed, having support could help take some of the weight off. How do you feel about bringing this up with her and letting her know you're willing to give it a shot?

I think she’d appreciate it. She’s been asking me to try something, and maybe seeing that I’m finally open to it will help both of us feel like there’s some hope. I’m still nervous about where to start, but I’ll bring it up.
